Without the Cursor ‐ How I Solely Use Keyboard to Control My Linux

Note that this is an incomplete solution since JavaScript has been so popular on Internet.And the skills cannot be built on a short time.

Case: Dvorak keyboard, Cangjie(倉頡) for traditional Chinese characters input, LinuxMint 20.1, average Vim user, upper beginner in coding, beginner in Linux.

Summary of Tools mentioned:

  1. https://www.byobu.org
  2. Vim
  3. Lynx
  4. iBus
  5. ntfs-3g (sudo mount /dev/sda3 /mnt)
  6. nmcli (sudo nmcli radio wifi off sudo nmcli radio wifi on sudo nmcli dev wifi connect [connection name] )
  7. apt
  8. KDE (activate by startx)
  9. Mozilla Firefox
  10. xdg-open

Keyboard Shortcuts/Command

  • within Byobu:
    1. Shift-F1: display its "cheatsheet"
    2. Ctrl-F2: split vertically
    3. Shift-F2: split horizontally (mnemonic: Shift is "flatter" than Ctrl)
    4. Shift-[up/down/left/right]: "move focus among splits" (original words in its cheatsheet)
    5. (command) exit: close the active split
  • within Vim:
    1. :vsplit: split window vertically
    2. :split: split window horizontally
    3. (normal mode) Ctrl-W + Ctrl-W: move focus among splits
    4. (normal mode) Ctrl-W + [positive integer] + [< or >]: resize splits
    5. :close: leave the split; close Vim if there is only one window
  • on KDE
    1. Alt-Tab: switch among applications
    2. ⊞-[Up/Down/Left/Right]: change the position and size of the active window
  • for iBus
    1. (customized setting)Ctrl-Shift-Space: switch among keyboard layout or input methods
  • within Mozilla Firefox:
    1. Ctrl-Tab: switch to next Tab
    2. Ctrl-T: new tab
    3. Ctrl-W: close the tab (close the window if it is the only tab)
    4. Ctrl-N: new window

my personal laptop opening sequence

  1. Login with username and password
  2. enter startx in the Byoku terminal
  3. press the window key, type iBus and start iBus
  4. press the window key, type Byoku and start Byoku terminal
  5. (for newbie in Byoku) press Shift-F1
  6. press Ctrl-F2 to split window
  7. (depends on your need) mount the NTFS files by sudo mount /dev/sda3/ /mnt/
  8. Start work/start study/have fun!
